Dear Sir,

I wish to thank the Department for the increase in salary they have granted to me. It has certainly been increased at an opportune moment. The present high cost of living and advance in cotton goods also, have made me wonder how I could continue instruction in Domestic Science and Needlework in order to make the lessons interesting. The Pama Indians, like many more people, are always wanting something new, otherwise they lose interest.

I hear Mr. Abraham is inspecting the gardens this week. I gave him a list of the pupils who were competing in the Home Garden Scheme. Mr. Abraham kindly consented to inspect for me the gardens in connection with the Women's Institute. Last year we had 14 who took advantage of the seed distributed by the Ontario

Department of Agriculture to the Women's Institutes. The judge sent me a very complimentary letter in reference to the competitors. This year I asked for 4 parcels of seed. As we have been requested to curtail expenses of a judge wherever possible, I thought Mr. Abraham could inspect the gardens for the women's Institute also.

I see no reason why we should not have a Fall Fair this year. Home Garden produce can be exhibited, and the girls have their needlework. They can also have an exhibit of baking and canned fruit.

I would esteem it a very great favour if arrangements could be made for Mr. Abraham to be present. October will be the best month I think. The date can be arranged later so as not to clash with the school teachers' Convention.

Sir,

Kindly oblige me by placing before the Department my resignation as teacher of the Senior Department of the Pama Indian School.

Last year I informed the Department of my then recently acquired knowledge of the fact that I occupied a subordinate position here. I enumerated the important subjects I had added to the curriculum of the school, and as instructor of those, in addition to the ordinary subjects, I asked to be placed on an equal footing with Miss Mc Bain. This request I understood was granted, when my salary was made equal with hers. I am so accustomed to the Departmental work of the English schools that such a position offers no difficulties; without any intentional disrespect to Miss Mc Bain, she evidently finds it difficult to co-operate. I can understand her position, for she has been here so many years. Therefore, as the latter arrival, I think it better to resign. Lack of co-operation will only cause regrettable trouble here.

I have, to the best of my ability, faithfully served the department for nearly four years, and I hope, given satisfaction. The agent and the former pastor, the Rev. John Nelson, can verify my statements in reference to my work.
On the whole, I have enjoyed my experience as a teacher on an Indian Reserve. In spite of its many difficulties, there has been a fascination, not only in the school work, but that of the community also.

Strictly accept three months notice, dating from October 1st.

Yours faithfully,

Ruth Waite

Sir,

I beg to report to Department that we have 3 boys here that will not attend school and I think it would be advisable to have them removed from the reserve & have had them placed in the lock up for a 1/2 day, and it made no impression on them for playing truant.

Their parents have no control over them and I might say are running at large. The Truant Officer has been after these boys and took them to school, but never would disappear. I would like for the Dept. to advise me what steps to take in this case, as they are bad boys and should be looked after.

Extract from report of R. A. Hutchison, Public school Inspector, dated October 20, 1917, on the Rama Indian Day School. Original on 152199/6.

There is some friction between Miss McBain and Miss Waite. It seems that Miss Waite has been assuming that she is the head of the school for two reasons,- First, because she teaches the senior room and Second, because she holds a higher certificate than Miss McBain. Of course, Miss McBain should be considered the head for many reasons, but chiefly because she stuck to her work when the conditions were not as pleasant as they are now. Now these girls are both doing good work and it is too bad that they cannot get along. You know, it is doubtful whether any two girls will get along for any length of time, living the secluded life that they do. The trouble is that they get too much of each other. I understand that Miss Waite's resignation has been accepted by your Department and it is well.
Indian Ed. Dept.,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

When Miss McBain informed me of the vacancy in the Rama school to take place at Xmas & asked me if I could suggest some person to fill it, my mind turned at once to Miss Erica Martin of Newport who is now making application for the position. I have personally known her & the whole family for fifteen years & have watched her during these years as she has grown up from a young girl. I have no hesitation in saying I do not know any person whom I think will fill the position better than she. She is one of the most conscientious & thorough-going workers I know of. She has a kindly disposition, cheerful spirit & delightful earnestness. Her moral & christian character is deep rooted & unyielding. To uplift & direct her pupils morally, intellectually & spiritually will be her greatest joy & she will shrink nothing too hard to attain that end. She will do it by love, patience & perseverance. The influence & training of her parental home is of the highest order & I feel sure she will make good in the school. While she has met many normal
in middle school training or had experience in conducting a school, yet she is not a stranger to the latest methods of teaching & I conscientiously feel she is fully qualified for this school & will give a good account of herself.

I most heartily recommend her to your favourable consideration & trust you will give her a trial until Midsummer at least & I think by that time you will wish to keep her in the position for she will far more than fill the recommendation I have given her. I have every confidence in her.

Yours respectfully,

George Carpenter
Missionary at Rama
Newport, Ont.,

Mr. Ingersoll, the truant officer, and the Indian Agent should receive instructions to prosecute parents who refuse to send their children to school. The present average of 19 is hardly enough for one teacher. Mr. Meyers is too lenient. You should write him regarding this.

The school should be supplied with the Ont. School Manuals. The lavatories are in a disgraceful condition, not fit for pigs to live in. The teachers blame young men and boys of the reserve. I understand that Mr. Meyers was notified some time ago to have notices posted on the school forbidding people from trespassing. This has not been done. Notices should be posted and the constable who lives next to the school should see that the notices are observed. Trespassers have destroyed the school garden for the last three years. Mr. Meyers should be instructed to have the closets cleaned out, also to support the constable in keeping young people out of the school yard.
Rama Indian School
RR No. 2,
Atherley, Ont.
May 30th 1918.

Dear Mr. Benson,

The Women's Institute is holding its Annual District Meeting in Orillia on June 6th and as Secretary-Treasurer of our Branch, I am asked to attend. The only train I can go by is the 6.30 A.M. from Longford so I am writing to ask if I may close school on that date.

The country is looking beautiful around here now. I wish you could come up soon and see it all.

I hope to be in Ottawa on my way to Montreal for the holidays, and will bring the things for the School Fair with me.

Am sorry to say Miss McBain's health is very unsatisfactory. The doctors say she must stay in bed for at least a month.

Your obedient servant,

Hilda A. Fawley.

September 3, 1918.

Dear Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your communication of the 31st ultimo, in which you make inquiry regarding the Rama school. The present Principal, Miss Eva MacBain, has not as yet decided to retire. She has been in ill health, but we are in hopes that she may yet be able to continue this work, in which she has been remarkably successful. Should a vacancy occur, however, I shall be glad to advise you, so that you may make a formal application.

Yours truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Miss Gertrude Ahner,
1 Bain Avenue,
Toronto, Ont.
"The little blossoms of Canada's earliest wild flowers."

And I would be willing to come to Miss MacBain's assistance with such a glad heart to help her in any way I might be able to serve her—for a short or a longer time—if by doing so seemed best.

My home is here in Toronto, but I am free at present to take up some other duties for a while, if I wish—and I would love to help in this Rama School, if I could help Miss MacBain. I am not thinking of any salary.

Yours truly—Gertrude Atwood.

Dear Sir:

I wish to thank you for your kind reply of Sept. 3rd regarding the Indian Rama School.

A few years ago I had the pleasure of meeting Miss MacBain, here in Toronto.
the Ontario Educational Association - at which I gave a paper - and Miss MacBain and I felt that we held close kinship in regard to our teaching work.

Might it perhaps be possible that I could come and help with the work at the Rama School - and thereby relieve Miss MacBain or help her in any way so that she could pick up in health? I am not thinking of salary but am just interested in the work there and the Indian children - and would gladly volunteer my services to stand by Miss MacBain in any work or service I could render her in her work with these Indian children - & by coming I could at least help Miss MacBain stand upright the spirit in which I am writing -

I was a great admirer of Miss MacBain as teacher when I met her & I am sure she must do wonderful work with these children.
September 11th, 1918.

Of course, you will understand that it is not possible for the Department to pay two salaries for the one position, and the monetary arrangements, if any, would have to be between yourself and Miss McBain. I would suggest that you communicate with her to the above effect.

Yours very truly,

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th ultimo applying for an increase in your salary as teacher of the Rama Indian School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is unable to grant you any increase in your salary at the present time. You are, however, being given a bonus of $150.00 for the current fiscal year and you will in a few days receive a cheque for $75.00, being the amount of the bonus due for the June and September quarters, last. The remainder of the bonus will be paid quarterly and you will receive cheques for the amount due at the end of December and the end of March, next, provided you are still teaching at this school.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Scott -

Our school which is a two-room country school and a credit to the Reserve and to the Indian Department which built it, has been left of late to the care of a half-hearted teacher. It is impossible for one teacher to properly conduct a two-room school if there is a good average attendance of pupils. In this case however, the attendance is small compared with what it should be. But there being no school board and no trouble with the system of operation, very poor, and certainly calls on the Agent and the Council to make some representations to the Indian Department so as shall bring forth an improvement.

Surely the Indian children are worthy of a better education, and surely the Indian Department is under obligation to see that the school is kept in proper repair, provide staff of teachers and also that other arrangements are made to bring forth greater efficiency in the education of Indian children on this Reserve.
Dear Miss Mrs Bain,

We were in the junior room for two weeks. Miss Asher taught us the first day we were there we did not like it. She told us to sit still with our hands folded. We did not do anything all day. She did not give us any lessons in the morning or in the afternoon. She would not allow us even to sharpen our pencils if they were broken. If she saw us putting our hands on top of the desk, she would slap our finger with a ruler. We did not read. I only read my lesson twice. Later she told us to multiply by multiplying by four. They are too easy, and she taught us how to write 123 and so on, as if we were babies. One day, she told us to come into the room to get all our books. We did so. It was on her desk. We all sat down there. She did not give us any lessons in them. I took some scraps of paper out of my desk. I did not like my desk being untidy so I tidy it up a bit. She made me put them scraps where I got them. And so, I was afraid of her she was cross. She used to say she was the same with children. But she does not treat them nicely. She used to kiss the little ones but not now. We asked her one day to go out for recess. She did not listen to us. If we don't get a new teacher I won't go into her room. I would rather stay here. I would be very glad if she leaves the school. She does not like Miss Carpenter or any body. I used to think she was a kind woman. But I don't.

Yours sincerely,
Cora Shelley

MR. SCOTT,

Miss Ahner, who was appointed temporarily to replace Miss McBain at the Rama Indian School, has proved to be a failure.

Before I visited this school in December, last, she had antagonised Miss Fawley, the assistant teacher. The Methodist Missionary informed me that he would have nothing to do with her. When Miss Fawley left the school Mrs. English replaced her, but she was unable to get along with Miss Ahner and left. Miss McBain, although not fully recovered, stepped into the breach, and is still in charge of the school, but she declined to occupy her former quarters there, as she said it would be impossible to get along with Miss Ahner. She is living at Longford Mills and walks back and forth from the school.

Miss Ahner has declined to have anything to do with Mr. Myers, our Agent, and he forwarded a letter he received from her, which reads as follows,- "Would you be good enough not come into my class-room. I think it would be in the best interests of this school to get rid of Miss Ahner as soon as possible, as
as she is not amenable to reason or advice.

RAMA INDIAN RESERVE

Three more of our soldiers have returned, R. Stinson, H. Shilling and H. Charles. We shall be glad when they all get safely home.

A couple of sleigh loads of the Salvation Army of Orillia came out here recently. The missionary opened the church to them and they gave a very good musical performance. Very few, however, were out to hear them.

The Ladies' Aid and the church combined announce a bazaar and social in the Council Hall next Tuesday, March the 12th. The ladies have been very busy for some time and have a large number of things for disposal in the way of braided mats, quilts, working aprons, clothes-pan aprons, children's dresses and underclothing, men's socks, framed pictures, pickles and many other things. In the evening there will be a programme of solos, duets, trios, recitations, etc., and the sale of home cooking.

Last fall the council passed a resolution and forwarded it to the Department of Indian Education at Ottawa, requesting the appointment of a school board at this place, but for some reason it was not done. Now the warriors feeling the necessity for something to be done to improve conditions in connection with the school, have taken up the matter and last week are circulating a petition among the parents, petitioning the Department to reconsider their decision and grant the request. They feel that a school board would make the school work under special rules and regulations and in close touch with the Department would tend to improve conditions, make the school more efficient and attain results more in harmony with the amount of expenditure the Department is annually making on their behalf.

REMARKS.-

Everything in the school is in such an unsettled state that it is almost impossible to make a report on the work. Rama, March 19, 1919

To the Indian Dept.

Dear Sir,

In fall the council passed a resolution asking you for the appointment of a school board for the Rama Indian School and forwarded it to you through the agent. In due time he reported and refused to appoint such a board. A short time after Mr. Benson of the Dept. was here on school matters and made the statement that you had no objection to a school board if it would do its work. We are, therefore, sending you this petition asking you to reconsider and grant the request of the council which is also our request, and give us a school board with definite rules and regulations for its operation; also setting forth what authority it shall have in school matters.

We are very anxious to have our school on a par with the schools around us which are supplied with properly certificated teachers. We feel it would be an advantage to have a properly constituted board here to keep in close touch with the affairs of the school, and to co-operate with you in making the school more efficient in order to attain larger results for the money you are annually spending on our behalf. We have learned that at a conference of Missionaries to Indians with missionary officials at Muncey nearly two years ago, progress was reported in every Indian school in the Province except Rama, and the school is not as efficient as it was then.

Other Indian schools are passing pupils through the entrance examination to the High School, but none are going up from this school or have ever done so. We should like to see a change in our school and our object in asking for a school board is that through it there might be a forward move. We do hope you will be able to see your way to grant us our request.

Yours truly,

I tried to be there and to see my results - he said, it would probably be the first or second week of January. He seemed exceedingly kind and sympathetic and interested towards my work. But the Inspector did not come. Why? I asked why?

There were such disturbing troubles caused towards me, very distressing and disturbing towards my work. People there, (not Indians) presumed to criticize my work who knew nothing of what I was doing, and were utterly incapable of judging her or my work. Why did not an Inspector call? Surely at a time of disturbance it is his duty to come and inspect and to pass his judgment and to give me his protection towards my work which I merited. My classroom was open to inspection, I was ready to welcome any Inspector, or any "qualified" Educational Professional. My classroom and my children were a gem of achievement. I have always loved my pupils and been very successful, but I learnt to love those "little wild flowers" best of all. I was exceedingly proud of them. My work and my children and my classroom were perfect.

I am not a "Visionary" Teacher. I am exceedingly practical, but I have "Visions" and I know how to make the child realize them, need to lift him up to those heights - through the strength that God has put into himself.

"I do Honor and Justice to the nature of a child" - that is my motto in child training. I deserved the appreciation of the Department and their appreciation and I merited
well earned 'hurts' and not blame, and such treatment as was served out to me. I feel hurt to the heart, my professional honor has been hurt. I feel it very keenly.

I am not trying to cast reflection on any person nor on any teacher there with me at the time, or who worked there before me.

Up to nearly Christmas time I had also to be caretaker. Shovel in all that heavy coal, and look after the heating of the furnace—and for the little private room. The agent informed me that that had to be done by the teachers. The other lady teacher (Miss Hawley) very wisely refused. He said he could have her dismissed for refusal to obey him—and I found him out later he seemed very keen to have a teacher "obey him" or arrange for her dismissal. I found this man absolutely false. What he said to my face and what he did behind my back were two different things. Why should a man like that be allowed to torture or worry a teacher? He was a person too ignorant to know my work. He became a perfect nuisance and most offensive.

The Indian master who came to my classroom all feet and deeply appreciated all I did for the children. When Mr. Benson from the Department made his visit to the school building he very kindly said to me that I showed he "good to myself." I thought and felt that
It was a very kindly remark—but I had not come here to be "good to myself." I came there to be good to the Indian children through my work with them. I can only be happy when I feel success in crowning my efforts, in endeavoring to teach a child in the most beautiful way.

The more I did for those children in the care of planning and preparing of my work, the more wonderful and quick was their progress and growth. I simply marvelled at them, each and all. It was all a great surprise to me because I had been told by those who had been, and those who are at the school that what I wished to realize was impossible—they were Indians, and I would be greatly disappointed. I realized all I expected from those children and more. I went there with the love for the lot of my work. I am a teacher of high professional standing and achievement. I had planned my work carefully until "June," as the department had asked me to do.

The hardest part of the work I had to do, in those few months that I was there. It was like ploughing a hard hard field, freeing it of all stone & debris, and sowing the seed. Why was I not allowed to go on with my work and to help towards its growth and rich bearing? and allowed to see the harvest? I surely deserved that. It was my right position privilege. My work was to be till June—for that my plans were made. Why was I literally thrown out?
Why did no inspectors come to see what I was doing? I am hurt to the heart.

I have a deep feeling of professional honor. I upheld and protected the teacher whose class I had taken. I also thought of her while at this hard work with these Indian children, so that when she would be able to return to her work in the fall she might find it easier to go on because I had given a "good lift." No one could have come to take charge of the classroom with a better spirit of "good will" than I had towards the teacher whose class was just into my charge until the end of June.

I was very kind to the Indian people—my heart went out towards them. I had never known nor lived nor worked with Indians before—but after a very short while I felt like a "sister" in their midst.

I had to do so much in the school building to make myself reasonably comfortable—it took much of my strength—the others there simply "grumbled" but I "dug in" and did the work. I was never used to anything quite so hard. The "home" had been stripped of everything to make the new comers' sojourn easier.

In order to come to do my work here until June I had to close my home and incur a great number of extra expenses, quite heavy ones... and...
The necessary personal needs with me for that time involved a heavy outlay of money, especially for that purpose.

In order to do the work I did and had planned to accomplish, I had to buy much for the children from my own money—much that I brought with me and some things that I bought afterwards.

At Christmas time I made a Christmas tree, all of course from my own pocket. I did not want my little Indian children to miss their classroom "Christmas Day." Later I was told that the Department allows ten dollars towards a Christmas tree. When I spoke of a Christmas tree celebration & closing to the agent, he shook his head "no, no, don't do it. He simply tried to dampen any wish I had towards beautiful work. He told me nothing of the fact that the Department allowed "ten dollars" towards a Christmas tree.

I had a Christmas tree—a beautiful closing—the parents all came. It was a joyful morning—but I had to do it all myself—with my own money. Why shouldn't my children have a Christmas tree? Doesn't God send us Christmas? Isn't it the greatest gift for the children? I wanted to cost of my
I spent a great deal of money, too much I gave away,
much I left behind, apart from the travel bill, the

Dear Mr. Scott, owing to my hasty departure

consequently several pieces of my best china became
with my broken valuable pieces very dear to me which I had brought in purpose because they were so pretty to use in extending hospitality towards visiting Indian mothers. I wished to lead with those Indian children & Indian People an "Ideal Year" of life, work, and love to give myself all and all to them in a Christ-like manner of service and work as a teacher according to our highest standards of educational proficiency. I stopped at nothing, counted no cost. I lived a life of self-sacrifice and was glad in heart. I sought nor desired no "White man's Company."

I also gave the children of my room & also of the Senior class when they became for two weeks my pupils, every lunch hour their cup of hot tea with milk sugar. For the winter there was very cold and many many a time had them come into my dining-room and shared my dinner with their little ones. I love to live and to do these things, but I gave my substance my strength. I gave it gladly. But for this did not deserve such treatment as was served out to me through the Letter from Ottawa.

I enjoyed the company of the Indian Mothers, as they would gather around me when school time was over or in the evenings. I spoke with them of what I knew was helpful to them, and what I could feel they needed. I taught them the "Mother Plays."
As we use them in our Educational work here in Toronto, and in our Normal School Training Department, the spirit of the true educational thought as it is begun in the kindergarten—this golden thread running like God's Spirit of Life through the entire school life of a child—if the teacher can only feel it and grasp it, and know how to make it practical and adjust it rightly to our prescribed curriculum. It is the golden thread upon which bead by bead according to the child's age and need the curriculum studies of our Educational Course places & can be strung, making the lovely necklace that will adorn the child, give him joy, gladness for his school education through his own joyful & glad & purposeful activity. Every child can feel the spirit of it, for it also is "life giving," and if the teacher understands it rightly herself & has it within her it becomes as it were her power to feel the child's pulse—to know whether the child's growth is correct.

I painted the clear white band of a kindergarten circle on the floor space in front of my classroom. I used it for so much of my work—a absolutely appropriate necessary to the needs of the age of these children of that grade according to the curriculum. Course of study as laid down by the Educational Department, and exceedingly helpful and necessary in the most practical sense of the word—for all their lessons. A skillful teacher knows how

That I was called a "Kinderartner" that was beautiful, though I am very sorry to say I am not a trained full fledged Kinderartner; though I have been one in spirit all of my teaching days. I just hold a Kinderarten Primary Certificate issued recently by the Department. I am a qualified experienced Second class Certificate Professional Ontario Teacher also holding Senior Matriculation and First Year University Standing—my discipline—the manners in and out of school of my Indian pupils was perfect—beautiful—I used no strap. The Indian Chief did not require it! They work with my pupils & all that they did & the manner of their life was spiritually perfect. Why should a public paper be allowed to make untruthful statements about me? Where was the Inspector whose duty surely it was to call & prevent & challenge such insults? Those statements were as false as why did not the Inspector come to see my work? It was surely getting high time.
How I wished I had welcomed him! A day with my class, as I had arranged my work, I knew, would have been a day of joy for him to have carried away with him in his heart forever. I am not given to praising my work or myself but in this case it has become necessary to speak up for myself.

When the agent would call, all he would say, with his hands raised up—“You are too good for this place! Too good for this place!” I have never heard such nonsense, or have I even been spoken to in such an absurd manner, or he would even persist to most unpleasant flattery—the man became positively peevish—he disturbed me with his very appearance at the door. The holiness & sacredness of the Spirit of Goodness & Truth & joy of High Labour that breathed into life from my children. When the children were not here, my own free time that I needed so for a little rest & reflection for my work & by needs there.

I needed the Inspector. I looked for him day by day. I needed him for my peace & my protection again.
The strange disturbance which was making my work so unnecessarily hard for me.

The agent positively discouraged all my endeavors—
he was a hindrance and no help. He is a false man, as

(for they are so numerous) their swarthy faces and beautiful trusting black eyes that looked into your very soul to see if you are true and then when they feel it give themselves in very truth of soul & trust back to me to guide and to help them on. REPORT OF INSPECTOR HUTCHINSON ON THE RAMA DAY SCHOOL.

Teachers,—Miss McEain and Miss McPhadden.

Miss McPhadden is a young girl and scarcely suited for her position. She has been attending the Indian dances etc., etc.

Teachers for this position should have a certain stability of character that comes with age. Young girls should not be engaged.

As far as I have been able to learn, the Minister, Mr. Carpenter is not trying to make himself very agreeable to the teachers. I am enclosing a cutting from one of the Grizilla papers, written by him. Something should be done to make this gentleman attend to his own affairs.

Reverend Sir:

I have to acknowledge your communication of the 23rd instant, referring to the activities in connection with the Rama Indian Day School and your disappointment in the departmental ruling, as explained to you by Mr. Agent Myers.

I have noted carefully the nature of the work that you and Mrs. McKenzie have been doing, and I am convinced that it would be in the interests of our Indian work if you were allowed to carry on with this activity. The danger in a missionary attending an Indian day school for the purpose of giving instruction during school hours is that the teacher and agent will feel that interference in the work is the result. One of your predecessors, a missionary at the Rama reserve, caused the Department of Indian Affairs no end of trouble, by tactless officiousness and continual "butting-in".

I have to inform you that the School Act for Ontario cannot give you the privilege of entering an Indian school for the purpose of religious, or any other instruction because the Indian day schools are managed by the Dominion Government at Ottawa.

The Secretary of the Department is writing to Mr. Agent Myers, rescinding the order under our letter of November 12th. Since that communication, the Department has undergone a change of mind, following a careful perusal of your letter, and after ascertaining that the vast majority of the Indian band at Rama are adherents of the Methodist Church, to which organization you belong.

I trust that you and your wife will carry on the work that you have begun and will take special care to see that no friction with Department employees takes place.

Concerning your second letter, referring to the skin disease on the Rama reserve, I have to inform you that the Department has taken action, and, if results are not speedily obtained, they will again insist on careful treatment.

Your obedient servant,

Barnet. I am pleased to offer you the position at a salary of $100 per teaching month, provided that satisfactory arrangements can be made for your children, if any.

Emphasis is placed on domestic instruction for girls and manual training for boys. The holidays are during July and August and a week at Christmas and Easter.

If you accept the position, it would be well to proceed to the school with a view to learning something of local conditions and planning for the coming academic year. Dear Dr. McGill:

I beg to submit the following report on my recent visit of inspection to the Rama Agency.

The one-two class-Day school was visited. Attendance is very good and the pupils are making satisfactory progress. Both teachers are efficient and interested in the pupils. They take an active part in Church and Sunday School work among the young people. Chief Snack complained of the teachers having a social dance in the residence for their local white friends and asked that they be dismissed. I enquired into the whole matter and found there were no grounds for any such action. The teachers have been entertained in a very friendly way by the local white residents, in return they invited these friends to dinner in the school residence and had some dancing in one of the classrooms. There is nothing to seriously criticize in their action and I would recommend that no attention be paid to any further complaints from the band in this regard. Both teachers are giving satisfactory service and are a good influence in the community.

Dear Sir:

On the 24th inst., Miss G. Swerdfeger, senior teacher at Rama Indian Day School, notified me that a number of the pupils had head lice.

I arranged with Dr. W.E. Brown, for a solution for treatment, and further with Mrs. Annie Benson, of Rama Reserve, to visit the school and treat whichever pupils required it. After treating for several days, and overcoming the trouble, the worst case after being cleaned up, again returned to school with another lot of lice.

It was therefore evident that the other children in the home that Herbert Sawyer was coming from were infested, so I arranged with Dr. W.E. Brown, to have the other children at the home of the father Ben Sawyer, also cleaned up.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I have to advise that Corinne Anderson, a pupil of Rama Indian Day School and a girl of fourteen years of age has become unmanageable. She is disobedient and impudent and is rapidly breaking down the discipline of the room. The teacher has strapped her without any good effect. I have now advised Miss Graham that if she can't control her, to send her home.

We have had some trouble for some time getting her to attend. Her father is away working and her mother has no control over her. She asked me some time ago to try and put her in an Indian School. I pointed out to her that it was up to her to manage her daughter but it has not worked out.

I am of the opinion that in the interest of the school this girl cannot be kept there and to simply allow her to stay at home would spoil the remainder. Kindly advise.

Yours truly,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Reference: 24-I-I

In reply to your letter of August 17th in regard to advertising for a teacher for the senior room of Rama Indian Day School, I would advise that an add in the Globe and Mail, Toronto would be the most likely to get results. Teachers looking for positions, keep their eye on this paper.

There are one or two things that it may not be out of place to bring to your attention at this time, in regard to the school. I have had reason to believe, in the past, that the R.C.M.P. had had some intimation from the Department to be very slow about taking action against Indian parents for neglecting to send their children regularly to school. Right now, the Indian is sitting on top of the world and is more hard boiled than before. The teacher finds it hard to get the Indian children to cover the work and when the attendance is poor it is that much more discouraging. In my opinion an example might be made of some, with benefit.

The second, is the appointing of a teacher to take the senior room and who is therefor regarded as the senior teacher in the school, who is junior in experience and who holds a lower certificate than the junior room teacher. This was done last year and does not tend to make things run smoother between the teachers.

These are two things that occur to me and are offered for what they may be worth.

Yours truly,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

It has just been drawn to my attention that Mrs. Olive I. Akiwenzie may have been appointed teacher in Sidney Bay Indian School, although I had definitely stated that I felt her academic and professional qualifications were not sufficient for this appointment.

Some weeks ago the local agent, Mr. F.W. Tuffnell, wrote asking me to recommend a teacher for this school. I have been working on the matter ever since, but only a few days ago succeeded in making contact with a qualified teacher willing to live in the Reserve. On August 23rd Mr. Tuffnell sent me an application from Mrs. Akiwenzie, and asking for my recommendation in connection with it. My reply in part was as follows:

"I note that this applicant has had but three years in High School and has had no professional training whatsoever. In my white schools at the present time I have three teachers who hold temporary permits but each has attended Normal School having failed on examinations there. I am not prepared yet to recommend any person with lesser qualifications than these. In the meantime I think it best to wait another week or two. If by September 7th no suitable application has come in it might be necessary to consider seriously Mrs. Akiwenzie's letter. Today I was in touch with two teachers whom I thought might accept the position, and I purpose contacting several more this week."

On August 27th I wrote Mr. Tuffnell as follows:

"After writing a considerable number of letters and putting through a half dozen long distance telephone calls I think I have secured a suitable applicant for the position of teacher in Sidney Bay Indian School. Miss Anna MacDougall of Kincardine informs me that she has sent you a formal application and I do not hesitate to recommend that she be appointed."
R.A. Hoey  
Superintendent of Welfare and Training

"Miss MacDougall taught for 3½ years in Haldimand County on a third class certificate which has since expired. She holds a B.A. degree from Queen's University and while securing this taught several summers in rural schools in the Prairie Provinces. She also took a short Normal Course at the Regina Normal School. During April, May and June of this year she supplied in a rural school in West Bruce under Inspector Geo. Dobson. Mr. Dobson informed me today that she had done quite satisfactory work."

Since my letter of the 27th two fully qualified teachers listed below indicated to me that they would accept an appointment in Sidney Bay Indian School. There are:

Mrs. O. Farrow, Second Class Certificate, Wiarton, r.r. # 4.

Mrs. Ina Shaw, Second Class Certificate, Walkerton.

In view of these factors it appears to me that there was unnecessary haste in appointing an unqualified teacher. If the appointment by any chance has not been made I would urge that my recommendation of the 27th be followed.

Yours very truly,

J.M. Game

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of September 3 and we appreciate very much the efforts that you have made to secure teachers for our schools. Mrs. Akiwenzie is an Indian and as the school is not a heavy one we felt that she could handle it for the current year at least. Her appointment has been made.

I am very much interested in the statement in your letter, that Mrs. O. Farrow and Mrs. Ina Shaw are anxious to secure a school.

We have a two-room school on the Rama Indian reserve, 7 miles from Orillia. The attendance is approximately 25 pupils in each room and we have living accommodation for two persons, attached to the school. If the two ladies just mentioned would be interested in this school, we would be pleased to accept them. The Indians on the Rama reserve have never caused us any trouble, and as the school surroundings are good, I feel that the ladies mentioned should be interested.

One of them could be appointed principal and the other, assistant. You would be the best judge of who should be named principal. Neither teacher appeared to be interested in going so far from her present home. However, I gave each full particulars concerning the school, your name and address, and also the name and address of the Agent. I have had no further word from these ladies but it is barely possible that one or other may have sent in an application. Mrs. Farrow has an eight-year old girl while Mrs. Shaw has a two-year old boy and a seven-year old boy. The former has good qualifications as she has taught two years in an Indian School and five years on the Staff of the Public Schools in Sault Ste. Marie. She holds a second class certificate.

I would not hesitate to recommend Mrs. Farrow as principal of your school. It would not appear advisable, however, to have two families of children in the residence, but one eight-year old girl would fit in satisfactorily. Possibly Miss Anna McDougall of Kincardine whom I recommended for the Sidney Bay School might be interested in the position of assistance in Rama School. Dear Mr. Hoey:

There is a possibility of our being able to secure the services of Rev. J. R. Hayward for Rama. Mr. Hayward is a Bachelor of Science and is, I understand, a certificated teacher, but of that I am going to make sure. I have to report that the discipline in the Rama Indian Day School has deteriorated to a point that some change will have to be made.

Both teachers made a good start last fall. For some weeks it has been apparent that all was not well in the senior room and I have given Miss Franklin my utmost support in an effort to rectify the situation. When the pupils started walking out of the room, I had the R.C.M.P. round them up and try and impress them. The police report to me that these big girls were so bold that they would even talk back to them. I have kept in close touch with the situation and on the evening of April 4th, Miss MacDougal phoned me asking me to come down before nine in the morning. In going into the matter with both teachers together I was informed that the situation in so far as the senior room was concerned, was completely out of hand, that the children would do nothing that they were told, were impudent, would go out of school or stay out as it suited them and the previous day, when the outside door was locked at recess, had smashed a panel out of the door.

Miss MacDougal stated that Miss Franklin had done her best, that the children had rebelled against all authority and that they were not going to do anything that they were not actually compelled to do and so far as she was concerned, she was not going to lower herself to the point of fighting with them nor had she the physical strength to do so, pointing out that these girls were stronger than either of them. She stated that she had liked the work but under the circumstances that had arisen, she would not be back after Easter. We discussed various possibilities at considerable length as to what
could be done. I instructed the teachers to call school and if the situation got out of hand in the senior room to dismiss school at noon for the holidays. I had a talk with the senior room and tried to put some shame into them.

There is no trouble in the junior room, other than a reflection of the senior pupils's misconduct and Miss MacDougall, in my opinion is doing a good job. I encouraged her to continue and assured her that the present situation could not continue and would not be permitted to continue and some change would be made for after the holidays. Miss MacDougall agreed to continue with this understanding.

Miss Franklin realizes that things can not continue without a change and thinks that if the following pupils were removed that possibly she could continue; Harvey Pavis, born Mar. 28, 1929; Joyce Martell, born Dec. 4, 1930; Shirley York, born June 27, 1930 and Geraldine Snache born July 6, 1931. I think it most unlikely that she could do so. I think that there is little to choose between these named and several others and that once control is lost it can seldom be regained. It will be noted that none of these girls are as yet fourteen and one is not thirteen. If these children are allowed to stay out of school, it will be only what they want to do and will, as well, have a bad effect. If they are sent to a residential school, I imagine, compulsion would be required. These are big husky girls, as big or bigger than the teacher.

Since Miss Swerdfeger's time we have only had one teacher, Mrs. Mary MacKinnon, who could handle this room and I think it would be indeed a very exceptional woman who could now handle the job. It requires a man.

I trust that I shall be advised in the matter before the end of the holidays otherwise I purpose not opening the senior room until some solution is worked out.

H.J. Weatherston
Indian Agent, Rama Agency.
Ottawa,

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

As requested by telephone on April 10, I instructed Agent Featherston to come to Toronto on April 11. At that time Mr. Doucet and myself discussed very fully with him the situation that has arisen at the Rama School, due to the fact that Miss Franklin is apparently unable to control the pupils. It was quite evident from the report given to us by Mr. Featherston that it would be a waste of time for all parties concerned to allow Miss Franklin to return to this school. Two alternatives were suggested:

1. Close the senior room for the balance of the current academic year. This would result in four or five pupils who are taking their entrance work losing their year and Agent Featherston was instructed to speak to Miss McDougal about the matter with a view to ascertaining if she would be prepared to teach these entrance pupils at least in addition to her regular class.

2. Transfer Miss Daly from the Caughnawaga U.C. School to the Rama School until the end of June. At the present time the attendance at the Caughnawaga School has decreased considerably and Mr. Doucet feels that one teacher could handle the school for the balance of the current academic year. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, in further reference to the June quarter salary cheque of Mrs. Ida Corman, teacher of the Rama Indian Day School.

The Department regrets that this cheque apparently has gone astray but this is due to some mistake in the mail, as our records show that the cheque left the Department on July 15th, last, addressed to Mrs. Ida Corman, R.R. No. 2, Atherley, Ont. The bonus cheque was mailed to the same address on July 14th, and, as she has received the latter, it is difficult to understand why she did not receive her salary cheque. Have you made full enquiries from the postal authorities in Atherley? The cheque has not yet been cashed, as we telephoned the Finance Department this morning and ascertained that it was still outstanding.

The Department is today communicating with the postoffice officials and requesting them to make immediate enquiry. You will be further advised when their report is received.

If Mrs. Corman requires any money, please advise the Department and an advance will be sent her.

September 16th, 1934.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Allen,

Owing to illness, Miss G. Swordfager, teacher of the senior room at the Rama Indian Day School, was unable to resume duties when the school reopened after the summer holidays. Her name should not, therefore, be included on the September Paylist.

The only entry on the September paylist for this school should be, as follows:

421 - Rama - Mary Smith - ReRe No. 2, - $850.00 - $85.00
Atherley, Ont.
October 12th, 1934.

MEMORANDUM:

Representative of the Treasury.

As Miss G. Swerdfeger has returned to her duties at the Rama Indian Day School, the following entry should appear on the October pay list:

421 - Rama - G. Swerdfeger - R. R. No. 2, Atherley, Ont. - $1000 - $100

421 - " - Mary Smith - " " " " " " - $850 - $85
Ottawa, August 6, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 9th ultimo, you may inform Miss Mary Smith that her resignation as teacher of the junior room at the Rama Indian Day School is accepted.

To succeed Miss Smith, the Department approves the appointment of Miss Ruby McNeice. She will be allowed salary at the same rate as the former teacher, viz.: $85.00 per teaching month.

I enclose Staff Questionnaire, which you should have Miss McNeice sign and return to the Department as soon as possible. You should arrange to have Miss McNeice begin duties on September first.

The teachers whose applications you forwarded in your letters of the 13th, 14th and 16th ultimo should be informed that this vacancy has been filled.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

A. S. Anderson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Longford Mills, Ont.
Ottawa, December 28, 1937.

Dear Sir:

Miss Swerdfager visited the Department yesterday and it was decided to allow her to leave Ottawa on Sunday, January 2nd. This means that she will not reach the Rama School until some time on Monday and therefore the school will not re-open until Tuesday morning, January 4/36.

You should so inform the other teacher and the Indian children.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

A.S. Anderson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Longford Mills, Ont.

Sir;-

In view of the fact that a new school building is likely to be erected at the Rama reserve, I would beg to make a suggestion for the guidance of our architect when drawing up the plans of the new building.

It would be a decided advantage if provision were made for rooms for the teachers who are to have charge of the school. For this purpose I would suggest that two bedrooms, a living room and a lean-to kitchen be provided for the use of the teachers. Miss Mc Bain, who has the school at present has a walk of at least two miles twice a day in order to get to her school and home again. There is no possible place on the reserve where she could obtain suitable lodgings. It is possible that her family may even move to Orillia in the near future, which would make it necessary for her to live at Atherly which is about four miles from the reserve. This would necessitate her using the train twice a day, and trains are not always on time.

I might say that this suggestion is my own and not occasioned by any complaint of Miss Mc Bain's. Miss Mc Bain seems to be a very capable teacher and one who takes a personal interest in her work among the Indian children at Rama. She deserves some encouragement in her work, which is rather discouraging under the present circumstances. I trust that my suggestion will be given consideration, believing that it is to the interest of the department's work.

I have the honor to be

Your obedient servant

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,

Dept. of Indian Affairs

Inspector

Ottawa.
Ottawa, November 22, 1912.

Referring to Mr. Parker's letter of the 19th instant in which he suggests the advisability of providing accommodation for the teacher of the Rama School in the new building which it is proposed to erect next spring I beg to say that I am well acquainted with the locality and heartily endorse Mr. Parker's suggestion. The nearest place where a white teacher could obtain suitable board is Atherley, which is about four miles from the school site. It will not be possible to secure teachers if there is this distance to walk. Miss McBain is able to live at her home, which is about two miles from the school, but to reach there she has to travel over a very bad piece of road. Should her family move to Orillia, as it is their intention to do, she would be forced to live in Atherley. I would recommend that this matter be dealt with when the plans are being prepared for the new school.

Martin Benson
Extract from report of R. H. Walks, Inspector, on the Rama Indian School, dated October 1st, 1912. Original on 152199/6.

I hope you will decide to erect a new school. Let me suggest that you follow the suggestions offered in "Plans for Rural School Buildings", a book issued by the Ontario Department of Education. There should be two class-rooms, cap rooms, teacher's room, basement for furnace, etc., proper heating, ventilation and lighting. In the class rooms the windows should be massed on one side admitting the light at the pupils' left, and the lower edges of the windows should be 4' to 4½' from the floor. This arrangement of windows permits the placing of blackboards at the front and the two other walls of the room. Much blackboard is needed for the junior pupils. The board should be placed low enough to be used by the smaller pupils. Single desks are best for cleanliness and discipline.
The Department of Indian Affairs.

Experimental Evidence.—That the above conditions could not have existed, had proper wall paints been used, seemed doubtless, and suggested a carefully conducted experiment to prove the relative sanitary value of wall paper and wall paint. A large piece of hard board, such as is occasionally used to replace plastered walls, was painted on one side with a high-grade wall paint, three coat work. A similar sheet was papered on one side with a clean, new wall paper.

These test panels were placed where unsanitary conditions, such as those found in the vicinity of air were present. After a short period of exposure the panels were taken to the bacteriological laboratory, and a small section of the painted surface, about two inches square, and a similar section of the paper surface of similar size, were removed and used for making cultures. In each case the surface of the section under test was washed with 100 c.c. of distilled water. The washings, which dripped from the surface, were collected in a graduated flask. One c.c. of the washings was added to bouillon, admixed with bouillon and again with agar agar. The enormous development of bacteria in the bullion, treated with the washings from the wall covered surface, was sufficient evidence of the unsanitary condition of the wall paint, the washings from which gave a culture practically free from bacteria. The colonies of bacteria shown in the photograph made of the washings from wall paper further support these findings. It may be stated that the tests made from the washings of the wall paint showed a practical absence of bacteria, and were clear, as was the bouillon solution test of paint. The washings from the wall paper showed rapid development of bacteria both in the bouillon and agar tests.

From the Conservation Standpoint.—It would be of interest to sum up in figures the acreage and cordage of wood that annually is transformed into pulp for the manufacture of wall papers. Unfortunately there are no available statistics on this subject. It is clear, however, that from the standpoint of conservation the use of wall paints should take precedence over the use of wall paper.

Modern Reasons for the use of Paints in Interior Decoration

Presenting a forceful argument for the discarding of hitherto unsanitary means of decoration, and adopting paint as being the most hygienic decorative treatment for the promotion of healthful surroundings in the home and in public buildings.

Paints for Interior of Dwellings and Buildings

Extract from article read before the forty-fifth annual convention of the American Institute of Architects, held at Washington, December, 1911. Presented by Henry A. Gardner, Assistant Director of the Institute of Industrial Research.

The proper decoration of the interior of dwellings and public buildings has become of even greater importance than the protection and decoration of exteriors. There is, moreover, an increased demand for more efficient and the production of more sanitary conditions than have prevailed in the past. Up until a few years ago, a great variety of wall papers of more or less pleasing appearance were almost exclusively used for the decoration of walls in the interior of buildings, and their application was commonly considered the most effective means of wall decoration. There seems to be no question, however, that the use of wall paper is steadily decreasing, and that the art of interior decoration is undergoing a change due to the almost universal use of paints.

Modern practice demands the maintenance of sanitary conditions for the benefit of the public welfare, and there is no doubt that from the standpoint of sanitation and hygiene, properly painted wall surfaces are far superior to papered walls. There is an abundance of evidence which shows that disease can easily be prevented and thus disease transmitted from wall papers. In the tenement houses which are common to larger cities, and to a lesser extent in the dwellings found in the smaller communities, where tenants are more or less transient, the continued maintenance of sanitary conditions presents a difficult problem. Infectious and epidemic illnesses generally leave behind bacilli of different types, which may find a culture medium in the fibers of wall papers represented by wall paper, backed up as they invariably must be by glue, starch, and other organic pastes. Occasionally the restriction of local boards of health provide in such events for proper fumigation, but too often no precautions are taken to destroy the disease germs which are caught in the crevices of the wall paper. As a rule, both tenant and landlord are oblivious to all conditions which cannot be readily seen or detected. Burning out is one of the most effective means of fumigation, will generally extinguishing and consequently fading of the delicate colors used in painting the designs upon wall paper. Washing of the paper with antiseptic solutions will destroy its adhesiveness to the plaster and often cause bulging and peeling deterioration.

Hospital Practice.—In hospitals, where it is necessary to maintain sanitary conditions, the walls are invariably painted, and requirements should demand the use of paints which can be washed frequently, so that there will be no possibility of uncleanness. Information of a prominent surgeon connected with one of the large metropolitan hospitals substantiated the writer's findings regarding the greater sanitary advantages of paint and brought forth the information that in hospitals under construction provision had been made for the finishing of the walls so that a hard non-absorbent and washable surface might be obtained. The same authority stated that the common practice, in apartments and tenements of covering the old wall paper over, with a layer of new, each time a tenant moved in, should be condemned, and that from a hygienic standpoint the use of paints instead of paper should be advocated in all dwellings as well as public buildings.

If such conditions are maintained in hospitals, where special attention is paid to sanitation, it would appear that similar precautions should be equally as necessary in public buildings and in dwellings—wherever, in fact, people congregate to live.

Dr. F. F. Geyer, Cornell University Medical College, New York City.

Sanitary Wall Paints.—Cold water paints or kalsomines should not be used, as they often contain glue, casein, dextrine and other binders which are easily destroyed. Oil paints which are thinned with turpentine and other volatile spirits, are the only real sanitary paints to use. These have recently appeared in trade a number of wall paints composed of non-porous substances prepared in paints having valuable water-proofing and binding properties, and of a nature to produce the flat or semi-flat finish that has become so popular. Such paints produce a sanitary, water-proof surface which is free of dust and dirt. By their use it is possible to secure a more permanent and wider range of tints than can be obtained with wall paper, as they are produced in a myriad of shades, tints and solid colors; from which any color combination can be selected. On the border or on the body of walls decorated with such paints, attractive stencil designs, which bring out in relief the color combinations, may be applied.

For the decoration of chambers and living rooms, dull whites, light gray, light and cream tints, and ivory whites may be used, while in the library and other rooms richer and more solid colors, such as greens, reds and blues, may be harmoniously combined.

Defects of Wall Paper.—It recently occurred to the writer to investigate conditions which obtain in many apartment houses in the larger cities. Inspection of a number of such places, in which wall paper had been exclusively used on the walls showed generally bad conditions; bulging of the surfaces caused by dampness in the walls, which had loosened up the binder, the wall paper peeling off, and pieces of the paper from the ceilings, were frequently observed. In many cases a shabby appearance was shown, accompanied by an odor which suggested decomposition of the binder used on the paper. The writer was impressed with the fact that such conditions could easily be avoided by the very simple expedient of using properly manufactured wall paints, which are water-proof and washable.

If you use M. L. Paints and obey the directions here given, you cannot fail to get a painting job that will be thoroughly and lastingly satisfactory to you. And, moreover, you will get full value for what you spend in money or in labor, or both.

Stir the contents of M. L. cans thoroughly, and from bottom to top. Stir a good deal longer and harder than you think is necessary. Then pour the paint, after stirring, from one can to another at least eight times. Twelve times is better.

Don't try to paint green lumber, nor lumber full of pitch.

Paint, applied to any surface actually covers that surface with a coat of mail, metallic oxides, in technical parlance. This plating, or armor, protects the surface from the mechanical actions—corrosion, or "oxidation"—of the air, exposure and from the mechanical action (in the case of paint surfaces exposed to the weather) of the elements,—rain, snow, chemical action, the attrition of dust, etc.

Every layer of this plating that is put on any surface—every "coat of paint," that is,—of course increases the thickness of that armor.

This is the reason why a priming coat and even two coats of paint will always outlast two thick coats without any priming beneath,—something it is usually hard to make the amateur painter understand. The oil in the priming fills the pores of the surface covered, and thus economizes the thin surface coats; and it leaves a thin film of metallic oxides on the surface which provides a good foundation for the thicker films that are on top of it.

The undersigned begs to report that, it being necessary to erect a combined schoolhouse and teacher's residence on the Rama Indian Reserve, in the County and Province of Ontario, and money being available from Parliamentary appropriations (Vote No. 302, "Indian Education"), tenders were called for, receivable up to noon of the 30th May, 1913, and the following tender was received: J. J. Link and Son, Orillia, Ontario, for $6,485.00.

The undersigned would recommend, pursuant to the requirements of subsection 2, of Section 36 of the Public Works Act, that the Messrs. Link and Son be awarded the contract for the work for the amount of their tender as above cited, it being reported by the Architect of the Department of Indian Affairs that the said tender is within the Department's estimate of the work to be done.

Acting Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
School and Council meetings have been held in the same building, which has become unsuitable for school purposes owing to being too limited. It is considered also that as no suitable lodgings can be obtained at the Reserve and the teacher has to walk two miles or more between the school and her home, the schoolhouse should contain a couple of living rooms for the teacher.

Funds are available for this from the Vote for Indian Education (No. 302).

The Architect of the Department states that this tender is below the Department's estimate for the work to be done.

Sir:

With reference to Rama school building, which I was instructed to take over from the contractor J. J. Link & Son, I beg to report as follows.

A meeting of the contractor and his creditors was held on Thursday evening, 22d inst. Those present were Mr. Link, contractor, and Messrs Gardner, Glenister and Pomeroy, creditors.

The account of S. Pomeroy for building material lumber etc. was accepted by Mr. Link at $318.81. An account of gardiner's for extra work amounting to $4.25 was also accepted. The accounts of Gardiner and Glenister for brickwork and of Gardiner for plastering were next taken up and considerable difficulty was met with in arranging a settlement.

It appears that the creditors had tendered on the work at the rate of $6.50 per M brick but had been under the impression that there would be 30,000 brick to lay. The kiln count of brick supplied to J. J. Link was 23,200 of which 935 brick were returned after the work was finished. It was finally agreed that the creditors would accept the payment for 23,000 brick and that Mr. Link would pay at the rate of $7.00 per M. This amounted to $161.00 and $5.00 for hauling scaffolding, making in all, $166.00 for the brickwork, $100.00 of which had already been paid.

In the account of Geo. Gardiner for plastering it will be seen by the tender that the price was 11¢ per sq. yd. Mr. Gardiner wanted this changed to 12¢.

In.
In view of their written tender and the decided objection of the contractor to make any change it was agreed to hold to the price of 11¢. Mr Gardiner had also been under the impression that he had done 1000 sq. yds. of plastering and had asked an independent party to go to Rama and measure the work. The report of the man who measured the work is attached and shows 899 and 2/3 sq. yds. This amounted to $98.97 and was settled at $99.

These were the only accounts brought before me and payment was made the following day in accordance with the above arrangement. I attach receipt in full for $1265.00 from J. J. Link and Son. The keys were handed to me with the exception of one which was at Rama and for which I took an order from Mr. Link. The keys which I received I handed to Miss McBain, our teacher at Rama. Miss McBain informed me that school would open on the 24th.

With regard to the broken blackboard and levelling of ground around the school I beg to say that the blackboard has been replaced. So far as I could see the contractor had levelled the ground quite well. As it will be necessary to do considerable grading around the school grounds in the spring it seemed to me that nothing further could be done by the contractor and in any case he had levelled all the he was responsible for, i.e., the earth thrown out from the excavation. In this connection I might say that, from what I could learn from the teacher agent and others of the nature of the soil, it will be necessary to put a top on of gravel and sand in order to protect the floors. The soil is of a clay formation and very sticky.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Dept of Indian Affairs,

February 23rd, 1914.

We have had forwarded to us by Messrs Phillips & Company our agents in Orillia a letter of yours of the 10th of February addressed to Mr. Myers your agent in Atherley.

We are very much surprised that you refuse to accept a coal burning furnace of our make in lieu of one of the Gurney make. It is a matter of common knowledge, we might almost say of public notoriety that our furnace is at least equal to any other make in Canada. In fact there is no other, not even the Gurney, which commands the same price. There is no other, not excepting the Gurney, which weighs so much and is so durable. There is no other that costs so much to manufacture, the extra expenses being largely upon economy devices, which will commend themselves to everyone with any knowledge of heating. Some of the best firms in Canada, notably that of the Cochrane Lidwe. Co., Sudbury, handle our furnaces.
Dept of Indian Affairs:

and boilers exclusively. There was a time when our boilers were manufactured in the United States and we expressly stated to one of your departments that we did not wish to compete, because in our opinion all goods possible should be purchased from Canadian Manufacturers. That time has passed and our boilers as well as our furnaces are made entirely in Canada. Not even parts being imported. We submit herewith one of our catalogues showing the apparatus turned out by us last year.

We trust that under these circumstances you will see your way clear to giving a fair field and no favor to all Canadian Manufacturers, efficiency being considered.

Yours truly,

DJM/K.

Introduction

Our primary aim in issuing this booklet is to bring to the attention of those interested, the importance of supplying fresh air to the children in Schools and to all in places of Public Assembly, by a proper means of Ventilation and heating.

This is a most important subject and absolutely necessary for the health of the nation. The backbone of any country is largely dependent on the Health and Brain Energy of the Children.

Our secondary aim is to show how and why this object can be attained more easily and more economically by the PEASE PATENTED SYSTEM of STEAM HEATING and VENTILATING than by any other means.
As to Ventilation.

You may have often heard the remark outside the Church door, "Wasn't the sermon rather dull to-day?" and perhaps you have assented. "Dearly Beloved Brethren," examine yourselves and the church ventilation and see whether it was not your own brain that was "dull," intoxicated by that most common of gaseous poisons known to science as "carbon dioxide" which is simply common air with its oxygen burnt out and replaced by particles of carbon.

Try a Simple Experiment.

Take a small piece of candle, less than an inch will do—light it and set it on a plate. Note how well it burns. Now invert a common tumbler over it. It still burns brightly for a few seconds, then pales—flickers—dies—not for the want of wick or wax, but for lack of oxygen. Now light again; cover again; let the flame sicken again; but before it dies remove the glass. See how quickly it lives again. It has good air instead or air vitiated by "carbon dioxide."

A Human Candle

Every pair of lungs is a human candle, but of many "candle power." The pure air goes into the lungs as into the candle flame. There the oxygen is consumed with the waste elements of the human body which had been absorbed by the blood, and which consist, like the wick and wax of the candle, chiefly of carbon. If a constant supply of pure fresh air is not supplied, the human body would be like the candle under the tumbler—weaken and gradually die.

The average adult inhales about 25 cubic feet of air per minute when at rest—much more when active—and exhales
about 6 cubic feet of carbon dioxide per hour, thus exhausting the vitality of at least 1500 cubic feet of air.

If more fresh air is not supplied, this leads to that form of smothering which the doctors call "asphyxiation"—witness the "Black Hole" of Calcutta and the horrors of prisons a hundred years ago. If only partially replaced, it leads to a form of blood poisoning which dulls the intellect and energies and blocks the avenue from the preacher or teacher to the "hearing ear and the understanding heart" of the listener.

Now if this is true—and it is—why don't half the people die when they go to Church or theatres or political meetings?

Because the meeting place is (like the tumbler covering the candle) full of fresh air when the people enter.

Because every time the door opens (that's where the man who comes in late is useful) it lets in just so much more air.

Because the windows are seldom tight and often open.

Because a healthy man may take a moderate dose of carbon dioxide—just as of whisky or other poison—without knowing what hurts him.

Because all modern churches, schools and other places of assembly possess some means of ventilation, even if crude and insufficient. That is why our forbears didn't all die before we were born.

Lessons Danger of Infection.

But there is another danger in lack of ventilation. The doctors tell us that nearly every human being, even the most healthy, carries in his mouth, throat, air passages and lungs, the germs of many diseases all alive and ready to work whenever they find inflamed or weak tissues to work on.

These germs (the Doctors call them "bugs") are more or less drawn in or thrown out with every breath.

The result is, in a crowded place of meeting, that there is a friendly interchange of microbes between you and your neighbors. You may have more diptheria germs than you
know what to do with; your neighbor may have a surplus of pneumonia seeds and another has a colony of measles or whooping cough embryos looking for situations. You exchange and carry your new roomers home, when if you can't feed them properly some of your family may perhaps be more hospitable.

How Ventilation Prevents Disease.

Comparisons have been carried out between schools well ventilated by mechanical means, and schools ventilated at haphazard or with no ventilation at all, which show that the average number of disease germs was only 17 per litre (or about 482 per cubic foot) in a well ventilated school, whereas in ordinary schools there were 152 disease germs per litre (or about 4307 per cubic foot).

Now, how will ventilation help this? Because by a kind provision of nature—carbon dioxide”—the breath exhaled—is heavy from air and falls to the floor by slow degrees, taking with it most of the disease germs which are carried out of the body with it.

In all good systems of ventilation the foul air is carried away through gratings in or near the floor and thus the poisoned gases and disease germs are carried quickly below the nose or intake point of the breath.

As all good systems do this we claim no special advantage in this regard.

But foul air won't go out unless other air is brought in to replace it. If it did we'd be worse off than ever, for no air is worse than foul air.

Therefore all modern heating systems for schools, etc., take in fresh air from the outside, warm it, and draw off the foul and exhausted air from the rooms, either by pressure or suction.

Suction produces a vacuum (usually by means of a fan) drawing off the lower stratum of air and facilitating the entrance of pure, warm air higher up.

But the disadvantage of the suction system is that it draws the cold air into the rooms through every crack and crevice in windows, walls, and doors, thereby causing drafts.
Pressure Systems Safest.

Under the pressure or "plenum" system the fresh warm air enters the rooms about midway to the ceiling, thus forcing the cold air out at the exhaust ducts near the floor.

Under a well planned "gravity" system the warm air enters the room at a velocity of 100 to 300 feet per minute; that is with quite sufficient force to squeeze the lower cold air "down and out."

But the most reliable system, especially in large buildings, is to force the warm air into the room by a fan or "blower" driven by electric or gas power at a velocity of from 200 to 400 feet per minute.

In either case the air pressure (except against a very strong wind) is from within to without so that there is little chance of drafts.

Of course, under any good pressure system the windows should be kept closed tight, as all the fresh air necessary is admitted through the fresh air flues. It is sometimes difficult to get school and church caretakers to understand this.

Responsibility of Modern Science.

With higher knowledge runs hand in hand greater responsibility. What our grandfathers did and were blameless for we may not do without adopting the philosophy of the man who thought he was not his "brother's keeper."

If there is anything well established by modern science and understood by men of intelligence, it is the vital necessity of abundant fresh air supply in churches, schools and other places where people "most do congregate."

Let those in control of such places think well how they can best do their duty to the human lives dependent on their care.

Pease System Patented.

So far we have claimed nothing for our own patented system.

Any good boiler with proper installation will heat and ventilate a building as well as ours—but at a much higher cost.
Note the name we give our Steam Heater and Ventilator—“ECONOMY.”

In the case of most steam boilers a large percentage of the incandescent gases go up the chimney flue, carrying “DOLLARS” with them. Every boiler must have “money to burn” in the shape of good fuel, but most of them don’t burn, that is completely consume, half the “dollars” fed into them.

In an ordinary tubular boiler the gases caused by the combustion of the coal travel from the fire box underneath the boiler to the back—then through the tubes of the boiler to the front and up the chimney which is located at the front—consequently a lot of unspent heat goes up the chimney and is wasted.

With the Pease System these gases make the same double journey as in others, producing the same steam, but we make them do a third passage, viz., from the front to the back again through wide radiating wings running along each side of the boiler from eight to sixteen feet in length and from thirty to forty-two inches in depth and then up the chimney which is located at the back of the Pease boiler.

The gases at the entrance of these radiating wings are of a temperature from 100° to 200° higher than at their exit by the smoke pipe.

This heat is used to warm the fresh air, which is forced under the boiler and up between the fire-box and the radiators on the inside and between the radiators and the brick casing on the outside, through the warm air ducts into the school rooms, etc.

All this heat (and money) wasted in other systems is saved only by the Pease Patented Steam Heater and Ventilator.
