Pease "Economy" Furnaces—“700 Series”

Durable. The construction of the “Economy” Furnace is simplicity itself. Life long durability is practically secured by the extra heavy fire pot and other important castings, copper bearing steel radiator, and heavy boiler plate dome.

Dust Proof. The expansions on all parts subject to expansion from heat, guarantee absolute gas and dust-tight connections.

Copper Bearing Steel. The Heat Radiator which has been a well-known and economical feature of the Pease “Economy” Furnace for years is still retained, but the sides, which have to be of steel, in order to give the greatest radiation power possible, are now made of a special grade of copper bearing steel, which, as its name implies, contains a certain percentage of copper. This enables it to resist most successfully the corrosive action of the gases contained in the smoke. Tests made of this copper bearing steel during the past four years have conclusively shown that it resists the corrosive action of acid gases for from two to three times as long as the best of the ordinary steels used in furnace construction. While this copper bearing steel costs us considerably more than even the high grade material which we have heretofore used, we have convinced ourselves by expensive tests that it will give more lasting service than any other steel we could use.

Large Clean-out Doors. These are a wonderful improvement and convenience and are situated one on each side of the feed door—thus enabling one to clean out the furnace in a few minutes at any time and without any trouble, by simply opening the doors and inserting the brush, no matter whether the fire is going or not.

Domestic Water Heater. As so many people now like to have their Domestic water tank connected to the furnace instead of the kitchen range—we have made provision for this in the Pease “700 Series”, so that at any time the connection can be made without taking down the furnace or drilling any holes. On the left hand side of the feed door, space is provided, with two holes, properly capped, in the casting for the flow and return pipes; this is one great advantage of a Pease “Economy” “700 Series” Furnace.

Firepot. Note the illustration of two firepots, (on Page 18) No. 1 shows the ordinary shape of Firepot as used in most furnaces. Although the fire is shaken in this pot, only the centre is fully cleared of the ashes. The sides of the firepot still remain clogged and coated with ashes, which, becoming wedged in, have no means of escape.

This coating of ashes on the sides of the firepot renders it impossible for it to give out the full amount of heat. Therefore, it is not efficient as heating surface.

Cut No. 2 shows the Pease Economy “700 Series” firepot absolutely straight on the inside from the centre down while the upper part tapers slightly inwards from the centre upwards.

In this way the heat rays from the burning coal strike directly on the overhanging surfaces which gather and distribute every unit of heat possible; none is lost.

This firepot cleans itself easily and completely every time the grates are shaken and as there is no waste of heat, it is nearly 50% more efficient.

The Pease “Economy” 700 Series firepot is on the same principle that has been so satisfactory and successful in all Pease “Economy” Furnaces. It is made in two sections, which fit one on top of the other with a cup joint. This prevents cracking, which so often happens with other pipeless pots due to unequal expansion and contraction caused by the fire. The centre of the firepot receives the greatest heat, therefore, expands most—our cup joint being right at this point allows for this, makes it absolutely gas proof, and insures longer life to the firepot.

Grate Surface. The grate surface is the controlling factor in the heating capacity of any furnace. Any one with the most elementary knowledge of the principles of combustion knows that coal cannot burn properly unless the requisite quantity of air is admitted to promote combustion.

In a furnace, the best place to admit this air is through the grate, therefore, if the grate area is small the quantity of air supplied is necessarily correspondingly small, while if the grate area is large the amount of air admitted must also be large. (See also “Air Blast” Page 15.)

The heat supplied by a furnace represents the amount of heat contained in the quantity of coal burned, less whatever heat is necessary to promote a draft. If, however, air is not admitted in proper quantity, there is a considerable amount of unconsumed and unburned gas sent up the chimney. This represents just so much absolute loss in heat.

In the Pease “Economy” 700 Series Furnace all this is eliminated. We claim to have a larger grate area, size for size, rating for rating than is supplied in any other furnace made in Canada.

That is to say, we supply more air to every pound of coal burned in a Pease Economy Furnace than in any other make. The large area of our grate allows the largest possible quantity of air to be admitted which is freely and evenly distributed through the coal. This gives a complete and equal supply of air. No coal, gases, etc., are left unburned, everything is used to produce the maximum amount of heat from the minimum amount of coal.

The saving made by this feature is very great indeed and alone forms one of the strongest features which has always made the “Pease” Furnace the standard for economy in fuel.
Pease "Economy" Furnaces—“700 Series”

The Rocking and Dumping Grate.

The "PEASE" rocking and dumping grate is far superior to ordinary grates for many reasons. It is most effective, yet very simple in construction. It provides the largest possible surface area because of special sockets in the ash-pit which give support to the grate bars.

The grate bars are extra heavy so as to withstand the great strain always placed on the grate in any furnace. It cannot be pushed out of position, will not break or bend, and is so deep in the ash-pit as to prevent even of a poker being passed over its entire surface at any time, if desired. Its simplicity of construction eliminates all superfluous cogs, bearings, etc. There is nothing to get out of order or warp. It is the most simple, durable, effective and convenient grate on the market.

The Vertical Shaker.

Connected to the grate bars is a vertical shaker which enables one to shake the grates without stooping. When the fire requires to be dumped, simply pull the shaker out as far it will come. The grates are then in a vertical position, leaving wide openings, through which they clean themselves immediately without the use of a poker.

Direct Draft Connection.

As will be seen from the cut, the smoke passes from the combustion chamber or dome of the furnace, through cast iron horns to the heat radiator, then through the radiator to the smoke pipe.

The horn at the back, leading direct to the chimney, is equipped with a damper so that when getting up a fire quickly the smoke need not go through the radiator at all, but by pulling the damper rod the large smoke horn is opened and the smoke passes DIRECT to the chimney.

After the fire is nicely started the direct damper may be closed and the smoke goes through the radiator and all around the dome, thus utilizing all the heat it contains before reaching the chimney. This saves a lot of heat that otherwise would be wasted.

Dome or Combustion Chamber.

The Dome, which is extra large, is made of fine textured heavy wrought steel plate, and is absolutely impervious to gas under all temperatures. This is most important, as the dome receives the direct impact of the hot gases and flames arising from the firepot. Lighter or inferior material would in time be perforated by these fumes, and so let the gas escape to all parts of the house.

The large size of the combustion chamber is a very important factor in making more heat by causing the complete burning of all the gases released from the fuel, which in most furnaces escape up the chimney and are wasted.

The close grain and high finish of the metal in the "Economy" Dome permits the rapid and perfect transmission of the heat to the most satisfactory degree. The remaining products of combustion are forced to the front and down through the dome horns into the radiator, adding still further to the heat producing qualities of the Pease "Economy".

Air Blast.

At the back of and just above the firepot is an ingenious device whereby a strong current of hot air enters the combustion chamber and mixes with the gases generated by the fire, insuring complete combustion. It has a sloping hood over its outlets to prevent it becoming clogged and it is connected to an opening in the outer casing.

The Base-ring and Ash-pit.

The base-ring and base are connected by radial arms, and cast in one piece of very heavy iron which gives tremendous strength. The ash pit, being all in one piece, cannot leak fine ashes into the air chamber which is the cause of the dust and dirt which accumulate in the house from ordinary furnaces. The ash pit is also fitted with a large door to facilitate the removal of ashes; also a separate slice door through which the grate may easily be attended to.

The Large Double Feed Doors.

The large double feed doors will be valued wherever wood is used exclusively or during the Spring or early Fall days when only a small amount of heat is required, because it enables the owner to use rough pieces that would otherwise be wasted. The lower door is fitted with a small wheel damper for admitting additional air when required.

The Water Pan.

Water for evaporation is kept in the large water pan located in the outer casing just below the base of the firepot. The water keeps the air humid for perfect atmospheric conditions at all times. A water pan is not required to such an extent with this furnace as with others, as the large diameter of the casings allows the air to be warmed without being overheated and burned dry.

The Dampers and Regulators.

There are four dampers in the furnace to insure perfect regulation. The direct damper, located in the combustion chamber and the smoke pipe, is operated by a rod from the front of the furnace and is designed to be used only when starting the fire or when adding fresh fuel. When closed, it causes the products of combustion to be drawn into the radiator, thereby
delaying their escape into the chimney long enough to permit their heat to pass through the walls of the radiator into the surrounding air currents.

At the bottom of the smoke pipe is the check damper. This should always be placed on the pipe below the smoke collar of the furnace. In the ash pit door is the draft damper. Both these dampers may be regulated by chains leading from the nickel-plated Regulator which can be placed in any desired position on the floor above.

Between the feed and the ash-pit doors is the dust damper. This is opened when the grate is being shaken and by drawing the dust over the fire prevents it escaping into the cellar.

The Casings and Linings. The casings are double, the inner casing being of bright Tin, and the outer casing of heavy Best Cast Staples Iron. This double casing is very important as it has the effect of keeping the heat in the furnace—the same as double windows keep your house warm. They are held in position by two steel rings and the base ring, and being of the same diameter from top to bottom, allow the air from the inlets to be distributed evenly over the radiating surfaces, reaching all the pipes leading from them.

The casings in the Pease "Economy" Furnaces are from 25 to 50 per cent larger in area, size for size, than those of any other furnace. This allows for a large volume of moderately warmed air instead of a comparatively small volume of parched hot air being delivered in the rooms.

Conservative Ratings. It has always been the policy of Pease Foundry Company, Limited, to give conservative estimates of the capacities of furnaces. Some people comparing our estimates with those of some other manufacturers, may fail to understand why some makers rate their furnaces having the same heating surface as the Pease No. 710 to do the work for which we have rated our furnaces as large as the No. 714. It is only necessary to say that the reasons that we have given in the preceding paragraphs prove that such estimates are made by men lacking in practical experience.

Rama School.

The school at this reserve is all that could be wished for. The teachers were asking for a bell on school and a small bookcase. The drinking system is poor, 3 or 4 pupils coming from consumptive families.

Sgd. R. H. Abraham.
Ottawa, July 26, 1915.

Sir,

Mr. R. H. Abraham, Field Representative of the Department, in his report on the Rama School states that the teachers were asking for a bell on the school and a small bookcase and that the drinking system is poor, three or four pupils coming from consumptive families.

You may order from the George M. Hendry Co., Limited, Toronto, for this school a school bell, twenty inches in diameter, at a cost of $16.00. You may also purchase a bookcase at a cost not exceeding $10.00.

The Department would like to know what drinking system is used at this school. If pails are used kindly submit an estimate of the cost of furnishing the school with tanks to hold the water.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Chas. W. Myers, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Atherley, Ont.

Sir,

In reply to above number and date I beg to say as to drinking system of the Rama Bay School there are no pails used for drinking water from. The scholars drink at the pump which I think is more sanitary than to have the water in pail or tank. Water in tank would become flat without ice. Our well splendid water. The cup is better to be in the open air than to be standing in the school atmosphere and more air less water in the cup.

I am your obedient servant,

Mr. Benson,

While at Rama, recently, I took occasion to visit the school. I found that the plaster has cracked considerably and in some places shows signs of falling off. As it is now about two years since the building was completed, it is reasonable to assume that any cracking of plaster that is likely to occur has taken place. I would recommend that the Agent be authorized to have the walls repaired where necessary and that they be tinted after being repaired. I think that the choice of color, for tinting, could be left to Miss McBain, the teacher.

Inspector Indian Agencies.

Sir,

I beg to report to Department as to the heating of the Rama Indian School which is not satisfactory. The registers are about left up on the wall. Scholars coming to school cold have no chance to get warmed on account of the registers being so high up, and they feel cold for a long time. I would also suggest that there should be a couple of registers in the windows so the heat being without heat, reaches into the school rooms. The South School room is all right with the registers up on the wall owing being to the south side of building owing to the strong winds need more heat and should have the registers lower down so the scholars can get the heat.

I am your obedient servant,

I understand Mr. Myers has written to the Department concerning the temperature of my room. It is worse than ever this winter. I do not think the average temperature for the last two weeks has exceeded 42°F. Last Friday it was 37° yesterday and today - 42°.

Madam,

With further reference to your letter of the 18th instant reporting on heating conditions in the Rama school, showing temperatures from January 10 to 18, stating also that both school-rooms were unfit for habitation, and the apparatus inadequate, I beg to say that the school-rooms at the temperatures shown are uninhabitable. The fault, however, is entirely in the operation of the furnace and not with the apparatus, which is one of the best make of hot air furnaces on the market and of ample capacity, its guaranteed rating being 45,000 cu.ft. and the area of class-room 18,215 cu.ft. only. The total cubic area of building is 30,000 cu.ft., and as there is a kitchen range mentioned in operation, that should keep the living quarters fairly comfortable during the school hours, after which the heat from the furnace is available. Messrs Phillips & Co sent their man to investigate the Rama Indian school furnace last Friday. 27 Below zero and wind running 40 to 50 miles an hour, a North wind. We found the North room very cold, the South room very warm. The corridor was as cold as outside itself.

This school stands in a bleak place; the wind from the lake has a good sweep. The front of the school facing west and so there 3 entrances - south, west, north. It is impossible to keep the wind out with so many doors. The front entrance and north door is not used. As there is too much cold and wind coming in the corridor from these doors around the fans, the hot air pipes act as cold air pipes in the corridor under these circumstances, and no heat from that source. The agent says he could get no one to do the work at the estimate given. I would, therefore, recommend that the work be done by day labor, with Alder York as foreman. This drain is necessary to drain the garden, the lower part of the school grounds and carry the overflow from the pump, which at the present time flows into the basement.

The basement has water in it all the time. No provision was made for taking the water out by means of a trap in the floor, and a tile.

The water flows from the high ground back of the school into the basement, through the outside door leading to the basement. See plan.

To remedy this the door sill should be raised 6 inches to 1 ft. and clay packed in next to the wall of the school with gravel over the top. It would take about three loads of clay and 1 ton gravel. The whole job, raising the door, gravel and clay would cost about $5.00

This wet damp basement is a menace to health of both children and teachers.

Ottawa, April 12, 1915.

Memorandum

Mr. Scott,

As instructed, I made an inspection of the Rama Indian School on March 25 and 26, last, and beg to report that the school is erected on rather low and level ground which does not permit of adequate drainage facilities during Spring freshet, the outlet of the drains from building emptying into an open road ditch which carries the surface water from a considerable area. The cellar drain and bottom of road ditch being practically on a level, the result is that when road ditch is in flood the water flows back into basement to this level which at the time of my inspection was three-feet in depth. To remedy this it will be necessary to either provide a pressure flood gate valve on the present drain, or, to build a tank with drain connected to building from which water can be pumped when necessary providing this enters the school basement.

Owing to the depth of water in the basement, no examination of the basement floor or wall surface could be made, but from due enquiry and careful examination of exterior walls and ground surrounding the building, I am of the opinion that the basement is in otherwise good condition.

In the rear of building it will be necessary to build concrete areas surrounding two of the basement windows, also to raise the wall of outside cellar entrance one-foot to provide satisfactory grade in rear, thus diverting surface water flow from building.

There
There is considerable repairing to the building required at this time, plastering being cracked and broken in each of the class-rooms, in cloak-room and passages, and also in living-room on upper floor. Interior woodwork is also broken in places and needs replacing; several door panels require repairs. There is a considerable space around the walls of kitchen floor which should be filled with cement to keep out the cold at this point. The exterior door and window frames should have the blind stiles removed and space filled with oakum or pitched felt before replacing to prevent cold entering the building there.

The porch over kitchen door is separated from the building and requires lifting and blocking up in front and securing to building.

The entire building (exterior and interior) should be repainted as the woodwork is very much in need of this, the original painting having been badly done (apparently only two coats instead of three specified) the wood having been left rough, without sand-papering, and visible through the paint.

The estimated cost of making these improvements is, approximately,

| Item                                      | Cost   |
|-------------------------------------------|--------|
| 4 ft. x 12 ft. deep excavation for drain well | $20.00 |
| Concrete curb with cement top              | 50.00  |
| Connecting & drains to well 30 feet         | 15.00  |
| Grading in rear                           | 20.00  |
| Three concrete areas in rear               | 30.00  |
| Interior plastering                       | 15.00  |
| Repairs to woodwork, etc.                 | 35.00  |
| Painting woodwork and tinting walls, etc.  | 150.00 |
| Hardware, carting, etc.                   | 25.00  |

$360.00

The cost may be somewhat reduced providing the repairs are done by the Band, under capable superintendence.

Ottawa, April 25, 1916.

Sir,

Plans and specifications have been prepared for drainage system for the Rama Indian School, together with the necessary areas and grading required to ensure for the future a dry and airy basement. It is also intended to make any necessary repairs to the building at the same time, including the broken plastering and woodwork, filling in around kitchen-floor, around all window frames, and thorough painting of woodwork, inside and out.

It is proposed to have this work done as far as possible by members of the Band, such as carpenters, plasterers, painters, and concrete men; and if so, the rate of pay per day for each class, and the date when this labour can be most readily obtained.

Ottawa, Ont., July 5th, 1918.

Sir,

As the Rama school has now closed for the summer holidays, the necessary repairs to the building should be made at an early date. The broken plaster in the interior should be carefully removed and all walls and ceilings thoroughly patched with wood fibre plaster in two coats. The damaged woodwork in interior should also be put in good repair. The porch over kitchen door should be braced up and firmly secured to building; also to raise and block up entrance to basement, raising the cement wall at least nine inches in height above the present grading. The existing doorway will necessarily be decreased in height and a new door necessary, and this will not then be of a stock size. A new door should be made of flooring or sheeting with cleats and braces on the inside.

Concrete areas to rear windows are also to be built to the same level as basement entrance. A drain well is to be dug to the depth shown on the plan near fence in front of building, with drain emptying therein. The well to be formed of metal tanks with top and bottom removed set on end to the height required forming case for well.
The space between the tank and earth wall being filled with concrete and cement concrete, platform at surface with opening for pump. Bolts to be also fitted into concrete for bolting pump in position.

The ground in rear of school between building and pump and on right end of building, to be graded as shown on the plan, so that water will have free egress from the grounds without flooding the building. Sand and gravel should also be graded over the surface of the clay in the graded portions, to prevent the carrying of mud into the building. A field tile drain is to be sunk into the grade as shown from well to fence, so as to carry excess water from the well.

It is thought that all of this work except the carpentering and plastering can be done by the Indians under your supervision with the assistance of the carpenter employed. The material necessary being supplied by you as cheaply as possible.

The plastering work and carpentering work to be done either by day labour or by contract as you may best be able to arrange.

Estimates should also be procured for the thorough sand-papering of the rough interior woodwork and painting of exterior and interior with one good coat of pure lead Linseed Oil, paint tinted to match existing work. Also the cleaning and tinting throughout the building with Alabastine in approved tints.
The estimates for the painting and tinting of walls to be submitted to the Department for approval before acceptance. The other work would be proceeded with as early as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Assistant D. M. and Secretary.

Indian Agent,

There are some repairs required to the closets and some cinders around these out buildings. There should be put some cinders around the school; this ground is very wet in the fall and spring & would think that 10 loads of cinders would fix up everything all right.

The teachers closet is combined in with the girls closet.

Estimate cost would be $25.00 + $5.00

The same would be quite sanitary. If a new closet would be required for the teachers by itself, this would cost about $25.00.

I am your obedient servant,

Extract from Inspector's Report on the Rama Indian School, dated September 20, 1921 - Original on 24-1-6

The grounds are rather rough and uneven. Organized play is good for the children. Just what you can do to improve the grounds or supply equipment is a matter for the Department and their representative on the reserve to decide. The rain beats in at the back of the boys' closet through the cracks and wets the seat. The door is off the girls' closet. The button on the outside of the door of closet is not long enough to hold it and it slaps in the wind. I would suggest that the closets should be scrubbed out every week if possible. I think that there should be a cup for each pupil and a place for each cup to be kept. A common cup on a reserve is a very dangerous source for spread of disease. The walls and ceilings of classrooms should be carefully cleaned at least once a year and paint used at least every second year.

T. R. Ferguson,

Inspector.
OTTAWA, November 5th, 1921.

Sir,

The Public School Inspector, in his recent report on the inspection of the Rama Indian Day School, states that the closets at this school require some repairs. The rain beats in at the back of the boys' closet, and the door is off the girls' closet.

I have to request that you will take immediate action in having these closets put in a good state of repair. Any work performed should be at the lowest possible cost to the Department.

The Inspector also recommends that these closets be scrubbed out at frequent intervals. You might draw this to the attention of the caretaker, as it is considered that it is part of his duties to see that they are kept in a clean condition.

The Inspector further states that the school grounds are rough and uneven. It is too late this season to have any work done in levelling the ground, but I should be pleased if you would keep this matter in mind and early next spring furnish a report as to what you would advise should be done to put the grounds in good condition, and also state the probable cost of this work.

The Inspector further recommends that a drinking cup be supplied for each pupil in order to prevent contagion among the pupils. I would be pleased to have your views regarding this matter.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Chas. W. Myers, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Atherley, Ont.
Sir,

I beg to report to above number and date as follows.

The Public School Inspector reports the cause of the big storm we had here the rain would penetrate anything with this wind. However, the closets were not finished in the first place. They were not lined up inside which should have been done. I will have them attended to.

I heard the closets thoroughly scrubbed when school opened, but owing to the fact that I placed new linings around their outside, trying to make the place sanitary and dry the block out of the cinders looked some, but now as the rain has washed these cinders there will be no more trouble as to trouble as to school ground being rough and uneven a great many school grounds are worse, at the same time it would make a big improvement to school yard to have it leveled up.

As to the individual drinking cups I could not see that would prevent catching as the cups that is at the well D'Gelbert's cup the fresh air is the thing as far as that concerned, no water is kept in school, and no plates are used. The homes is were this trouble started.

I am your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Ass't Deputy and Secretary
of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Sir,

I have been requested by the teacher of Roma Day School to secure for them if possible the following articles:

1 Small Galvanized Pail for kitchen use
1 Wash Stand for Kitchen use

The Women's Institute of Roma have promised to the school a supply of Tooth Brushes sufficient for each pupil and they have asked for a supply of Tooth Powder and cups for use when pupils are cleaning their teeth and also some kind of a tank that the water for use can be drawn from.

There is also the question of drinking from the pump in the school yard. It is not practical to leave a cup at the pump for it would become the common property of the Reserve for drinking purposes which is not advisable. A small outlay might be made and a cup purchased for each pupil for drinking purposes.

There is also considerable space at the bottom of the door leading from the School Hallway into the teacher's kitchen, and every day when the sweeping is done considerable...
Sir,

A small mat laid at the door would prevent the dust getting through.

A broom stick is also required.

A cupboard used by teachers for keeping supplies in requires repairing and a new lock.

On an inspection of the school I find that a number of the locks are broken and there are no keys whatever for any doors. I enquired from the old caretaker and she stated she had no keys and did not know where they were. Kindly let me have your instructions and oblige.

Yours truly,

R.S. Andrews, Agent
Rama Indian Reserve

Sir:

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, relative to the painting of the interior and exterior of the Rama Indian Day School building during the coming summer holidays. It is noted that you will obtain an estimate of the cost of having this work done.

In this connection it is considered that the amount required should be provided from the interest funds at the credit of the Band. After you have obtained an estimate of the cost, you should submit the matter to the Band in Council, and, if possible, obtain a resolution authorizing the Department to pay the expenditure incurred from the interest account at the credit of the Band. It is hoped that the Council will willingly consent to provide the funds. I might say that it is unlikely that the funds required to pay the cost of the painting could be provided from Parliamentary Appropriation, and in the event of the Indians refusing to provide the funds necessary this work would have to stand over.

Regarding the extension of the electric light system to the classrooms, we will await your estimate of the cost involved before giving consideration to authorizing the work being done. This matter was only brought up on the recommendation of the Public School Inspector, as, owing to the period each day the classes are held, the Department is unable to see the necessity for providing electric light to carry on the work.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, submitting an estimate of the cost of installing electric lights in the classrooms of the Rama Indian Day School, and also with reference to the painting of the school building.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the installation of two lights in front of each blackboard in each classroom with suitable shades or reflectors, also for the installation of a switch for each room as required. It is noted that you estimate the cost of this work to be approximately $35, and this amount should, if possible, not be exceeded. When the work has been completed, you should furnish properly certified vouchers covering the cost.

With reference to obtaining prices for the painting of the interior and exterior of the school building, I beg to say that if tenders are called it would be necessary to submit the same to His Excellency the Governor General In Council for approval. We would prefer that you obtain an estimate from a reliable painter of the cost of the material required, such as paint, oils, etc., and a separate estimate for the labour in doing the painting. Another arrangement that would be satisfactory would be for you to purchase the material after obtaining competitive prices, and arrange for the labour under a competent foreman, keeping time sheets for the men engaged. Please forward the estimate of the cost of the material and labour, and state which of the above arrangements you prefer for having the work done. It will be necessary to prepare a brief specification of the amount of painting to be done, and I shall also be pleased to have this information.

The question of authorizing the work during the coming summer holidays will depend entirely upon obtaining a resolution from the Band in Council to authorize the Department to pay the expenditure required from the interest account at the credit of the Band, and you should, after ascertaining what the cost will be, endeavour to obtain this resolution for the amount required.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. S. Anderson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Longford Mills, Ont.
Ottawa, March 18th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, recommending that crushed stone be secured and placed on the walks and approaches to the Rama Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that, when weather conditions permit, you may arrange to obtain the quantity of crushed stone required and have it hauled from Longford and placed on the walks and approaches. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred for the purpose, and you will see that this work is satisfactorily carried out and the walks left in a neat and finished condition.

You may also purchase and have installed a gate at the entrance to the school grounds, also a padlock for the teacher's outdoor closet.

The Department will also approve of the purchase of a load of well rotted manure and a few loads of loam for the flower beds on the school grounds.

You should furnish properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, showing the expenditure incurred for each of the above services.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, with reference to the conditions of the engagement of Mrs. Stickle, newly appointed senior teacher at the Rama Indian Day School. It is true that the Department is particularly interested in household science, but I am not prepared to authorize the supplying of a sewing machine at the present time. Later, after the work is well under way, if this equipment appears to be urgently needed, you may again bring the matter to the attention of the Department.

There is no change of policy in connection with what should be supplied to the teachers at this school, but I wish to make Mrs. Stickle feel as comfortable as possible. In my offer to her, I stated that the necessary furniture and equipment, with the exception of linens, etc., was provided. I mentioned that fuel was supplied by the Department and a janitor employed. I consider that the teachers should continue to pay the electric light charges and supply the smallware, etc., necessary.

With reference to the time table and course of studies to be followed, you may inform Mrs. Stickle that the Department wishes her to be guided by the curriculum prescribed by the Ontario Department of Education. She should give the practical work particular emphasis and should endeavour to correlate classroom exercises with the activities of the children's homes and environment. You might refer Mrs. Stickle to the advice and instructions printed on the covers of the classroom register.

Your obedient servant,

A. S. Anderson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Longford Mills,
Ont.

Dear Sir:

While at the Rama Reserve this week, I noticed that the school needs painting very badly. The outside weed trimmings are deteriorating very rapidly. This school should have been painted four or five years ago. I asked the agent about it, and he stated that the Indian Council would not pass any resolution. I beg to recommend that funds of the band be used, and the school painted. The metal capping on the belfry and chimneys should also be painted as they are rusting badly.

The agent also informed me that he had a letter of instructions from the Department stating that he was to prepare for a school garden. In this connection I wish to point out that the soil in the school yard is not suitable for a garden. We tried our best to have a garden and make a success of it this last number of years, but the ground is very hard tough clay. One end of it is very wet and low, and before anything could be done a tile drain would have to be put in. I surveyed for this tile drain a number of years ago, but it was not put in. I do not think that the idea of having a garden at the school is practical. The school children have been having their gardens at home, and the produce has been exhibited at the fair. The big problem with the school garden is that during the summer holidays, when the children are not at school and the teachers are not on the Reserve, the garden goes to weeds and not only that but it is a disgrace, setting a very poor example for the children.

I beg to recommend that the children continue on the basis of their home plot, rather than a school garden.

Yours truly,

J.D. McLean, Esq.,
The Secretary,
Dept. of Ind. Aff.,

Sir,

I beg to advise that in the basement of the Roma Indian Day School a certain amount of water lodges there and lately it has been very bad. I examined it on Thursday last, and from observation it would appear to me to be necessary to take levels to find out if there is sufficient drop for proper drainage. Provided you have the plans when the school was built, I am of the impression it will show a drain from the North West corner of School to a well, a little west of School, and from this well another drain was made but I am informed was never connected to the well.

I cannot advise opening these drains until it is certain that proper drainage can be had.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, relative to the oiling of the floors in the classrooms at the Rama Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of having these floors oiled three times each year, at intervals of approximately 4 months. The floors should first be scrubbed and allowed to thoroughly dry, after which the oil should be applied. You may arrange for the purchase of the oil required for the purpose. Mr. A. S. Anderson, Agent,
Longford, Ont.

Dear Mr. Anderson:

In discussing the problem of a school picnic before the end of June, Miss Kellogg and I wondered if it would be permissible to arrange an Educational trip, say to Port McNall to the docks, or some such place, just for the pupils from 10 years of age up. We could take them with us and combine Geography, History and Picnic. There would be the expense of a truck or conveyance of that kind. Do you think the Department would be willing to bear the expense. If you could go along and Rev. & Mrs. MacKenzie as well as we two teachers, the children would be well taken care of. They see so little of the real Canada, it would be good for them.

Yours truly,

Jean Stickley
Principal

Sir,

I have been requested by the teachers of Rama Indian Day School to arrange for a one day outing or picnic for pupils from 10 years of age up. Ottawa, June 15, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, with reference to water in the basement of the Rama Indian Day School. I cannot agree to the provision of a wooden floor in the coalbins. Mr. Orr will visit the school in the early future and action will be taken following his report.

I have also your letter of the 11th instant, asking for a grant for an educational trip, or picnic, for the older pupils of this school. This scheme commands itself to the Department and I have to authorize you to expend the sum of not more than $24 for a school outing.
